bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, January 10, 1929

div1.p: Carter is sick with the flu, but she continues to work on the revision of bibliographical references for the History of Yellow Fever at home.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, January 10, 1929
div1.opener:
Book
Misel, Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
January 10, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Miss Brown and I have put in some very satisfactory work since
I last wrote you, on New Year's Day.

Miss Brown finished the duplicates of the library cards, which I
had had to take from Dr. Frost's files for the History of Yellow Fever, on
Monday night, January 7th. She went on sick leave. “flu,” I fear, on Tues-
day morning, January 8th. I've been confined to the house, though not to bed,
since January 1st. with a light, though typical, attack of flu. Indeed, Dr.
Leake, of the Public Health Service, says that I probably (from my clinical
history) developed it on December 29th.--i. e. from my direct exposure to it
in Baltimore. This has, however, interfered very little with the work on
the book, since, as I wrote you, themy work, as planned by Dr. Frost, could
be best done at home in the immediate future. This is being done in an
“atmosphere” of “Hopkins gargle,” Sloan's linimmahtment and sodium salicylate--
the last two because the “flu” has greatly intensified a neuritis I have had
in my right arm for the past two months. Fortunately, the “mechanics of
typewriting” hurt it less than writing by hand, so the work on the revision
of the bibliographic cards can go on, although not so rapidly as I had
hoped. I wish that I could get someone else to work on them also, but the
work is too highly specialized for anyone not familiar with our previous
work and Miss Brown does not use a typewriter. I hope, and expect, however,
to have the remaining bibliographic cards rewritten and rearranged, according to
Dr. Frost's plan, by the time he is ready for them, and hope still more that
his extra work, on account of the flu, may soon be so arranged as to per-
mit of his completing the final editing of Father's Ms. But for the flu,
flu,
-2-
his own illness and his subsequent epidemiological work, the MS should
have been ready to go to press e'er now. Its a great disappointment, but
I trust that things may clear up soon. Also, Frost is well worth waiting
for! I think that, during my last stay in Baltimore, Frost did get the
first two Sections of Father's MS just as he wanted them for their final
typing. This, thanks to the copy of Villalba, gotten for us by the Library
of the Surgeon General of the Army, from which Miss Brown and I had made
copious extracts before I went to Baltimore with the verified bibliographic
cards for Villalba.

With heartfelt good wishes, and don't get the flu under any con-
ditions! I'd forgotten, even my after my last year's experience, how
many muscles there are to ache!
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
